channel.title: State-Policy Think-Tank Digest
channel.description: Latest posts from free-market policy institutes across the U.S.

item.title: [Mspolicy] HB2 – Mississippi’s School Choice Bill is Here!
item.description:
Last week, House Speaker Jason White unveiled HB2, the Mississippi Education Freedom Act - the most exciting and ambitious advancement for school choice in our state in years, perhaps ever! This comprehensive bill delivers everything supporters of parental power have long hoped for, and it aligns perfectly with President Trump’s strong commitment to education freedom. This isn’t some minor […]

The post HB2 – Mississippi’s School Choice Bill is Here! appeared first on Mississippi Center for Public Policy.

item.title: [Riograndefoundation] ABQ Journal opinion piece: More investigative journalism is a must
item.description:
The following appeared in Albuquerque Journal on January 11, 2026. The Albuquerque Journal recently made appeals on its pages for donations to increase investigative journalism efforts. Even though the Rio Grande Foundation is in direct competition for limited donor dollars, we applaud the paper for focusing attention on investigative journalism currently. The issue of investigative journalism is […]

The post ABQ Journal opinion piece: More investigative journalism is a must appeared first on Rio Grande Foundation.

item.title: [Riograndefoundation] ABQ Ethics Board Dismisses frivolous “sweatshirt-gate” ethics complaint made by Keller campaign against RGF’s Paul Gessing
item.description:
This afternoon in a hearing, the Albuquerque Board of Ethics (BOE) unanimously dismissed a complaint filed by Daymon Ely for the Tim Keller campaign that was made against Rio Grande Foundation president Paul Gessing. The complaint arose out of the Foundation’s reporting over the purchase and delivery of yellow hoodie sweatshirts to members of Albuquerque’s […]

The post ABQ Ethics Board Dismisses frivolous “sweatshirt-gate” ethics complaint made by Keller campaign against RGF’s Paul Gessing appeared first on Rio Grande Foundation.

item.description:
2026 State of the State Response On Wednesday evening, Governor Patrick Morrisey delivered his annual State of the State address, outlining his priorities for the year ahead and offering a window into his governing philosophy. As is customary, the speech functioned as both pep rally and agenda-setting exercise. State of the state addresses tend to […]

Michelle Lujan Grisham, with the […]

item.title: [Will Law] Bothfield v. WEC & WBLD v WEC
item.description:
On behalf of Wisconsin voters in all 8 of the state's congressional districts, WILL filed motions to intervene in two lawsuits seeking to overturn Wisconsin’s Congressional Maps. Seeking again to defend those maps on behalf of a group of Wisconsin voters, WILL argues that these new lawsuits are time-barred, the three-judge panel lacks authority to overrule the Wisconsin Supreme Court, and any attempt to impose new maps in this manner would violate federal law and the U.S. Constitution.

The post Bothfield v. WEC & WBLD v WEC appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.title: [Rifreedom] “Doc” Skoly Stepping Down as Center’s Chair to Pursue Congressional Seat
item.description:
The Rhode Island Center for Freedom & Prosperity announced today that Dr. Stephen "Doc" Skoly has stepped down as Chairman of its Board of Directors to pursue a run for the US House of Representatives in Rhode Island's second Congressional district.

The post “Doc” Skoly Stepping Down as Center’s Chair to Pursue Congressional Seat appeared first on RI Center for Freedom and Prosperity.

item.title: [Platteinstitute] Policy Pathway for Principled Tax Reform
item.description:
Policy Pathway for Principled Tax Reform outlines a framework for evaluating tax policy through the lens of sound tax principles including transparency, simplicity, stability, neutrality, and economic efficiency. The report examines Nebraska’s major tax types including property, income, and sales and offers practical, principle-based recommendations to improve affordability, competitiveness, and long-term fiscal sustainability. While designed...

The post Policy Pathway for Principled Tax Reform appeared first on Platte Institute.

item.title: [Cardinalinstitute] Healthcare in West Virginia
item.description:
Healthcare in West Virginia Healthcare policy is complicated. These resources make it understandable. If you are trying to make sense of West Virginia’s latest healthcare debates, you are not alone. PBM regulation, PEIA’s recurring funding crises, and Certificate of Need laws all affect what care costs, where it is available, and who has choices. We […]

The post Healthcare in West Virginia appeared first on Cardinal Institute.

item.title: [Will Law] Wisconsin Senate Passes WILL-Backed ﻿Amendment to End Tax-Veto Loopholes
item.description:
WILL issued a statement applauding the Wisconsin State Senate for passing Senate Joint Resolution 116 (SJR 116). This proposed amendment to the Wisconsin Constitution curbs executive overreach by prohibiting the governor from using the partial veto to create or increase taxes or fees.

The post Wisconsin Senate Passes WILL-Backed ﻿Amendment to End Tax-Veto Loopholes appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.title: [Will Law] WILL-Backed Equality Amendment ﻿On November 2026 Ballot
item.description:
The “Equality Amendment,” otherwise known as Assembly Joint Resolution 102 (AJR 102) will be on the November 2026 ballot after the Wisconsin State Senate voted in favor today. The Wisconsin State Assembly passed the amendment last week.

The post WILL-Backed Equality Amendment ﻿On November 2026 Ballot appeared first on Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty.

item.description:
A bill to create universal open enrollment for New Hampshire public schools is already prompting school boards to consider marketing their districts to families. And the bill hasn’t passed either chamber of the Legislature yet. Senate Bill 101, sponsored by Sen. Tim Lang, R-Sanbornton, would require all school districts to “establish an open enrollment policy […]

item.title: [Mspolicy] If You Want Parent Power, Only HB2 Will Do
item.description:
Over the past few years, Mississippi lawmakers have passed some critical conservative reforms. Last year, Mississippi became the first state in America to legislate to eliminate the income tax in 40 years.  In 2022, we implemented flat tax reform.  A few years before that, we passed important labor market reforms.  In 2024, we reformed school funding […]

item.title: [Jbartlett] Open enrollment: Know the basics
item.description:
In 2025, New Hampshire legislators passed a law allowing students to enroll in any public school within their assigned district, as long as the school had room. This year, lawmakers might allow students to enroll in any New Hampshire public school that has room. This policy brief answers six core questions commonly raised about open […]

item.title: [Badgerinstitute] A foolish law wages war against homemade shindigs
item.description:
The law, passed in 2023, decrees that venues rented for private events at which the people holding the party bring their own alcohol can host only six such events a year, and only one a month — unless they prohibit bring-your-own drinks and instead get a liquor license like a tavern. Those are subject to strict quotas. Town board can simply refuse.

The post A foolish law wages war against homemade shindigs appeared first on Badger Institute.

item.title: [Jbartlett] New housing permits are highest since 2006, but single-family homes lag
item.description:
New Hampshire towns and cities are permitting more residential housing units than they have in years, which is great news. But the new units are skewed heavily toward rentals, suggesting that local restrictions on small, single-family homes remain a significant barrier. Local governments issued permits for 5,822 new housing units in 2024, the highest number […]

item.title: [Pioneerinstitute] A Steady-State Budget in a Moment of Crisis
item.description:
Governor Maura Healey’s fiscal year 2027 budget totals $62.8 billion, a 3.8 percent year-over-year increase. The budget avoids sweeping new initiatives and largely preserves existing structures. That might be defensible in a period of stability. It is indefensible now. 

The post A Steady-State Budget in a Moment of Crisis  appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

item.title: [Alabamapolicy] The Numbers Don’t Lie: The CHOOSE Act is Empowering Alabama’s Families
item.description:

item.description:

A strong country will have strong AI because it powers advancements across sectors and generates...

item.title: [Mainepolicy] Governor Mills’s Supplemental Budget Abandons Fiscal Discipline, Sets Maine Up for Higher Costs
item.description:
Governor Janet Mills’ FY 2026 supplemental budget marks a clear break from the fiscal restraint her administration often claimed to practice. Rather than using Maine’s strong revenue growth to stabilize taxpayers after years of tax increases and inflation, the proposal dramatically expands spending, broadens emergency powers, and doubles down on distortionary tax policy choices that […]

item.title: [Pacificresearch] House GOP must promote commonsense health care reform
item.description:
Nearly half of Americans struggle to pay for health care, according to recent polling from independent health policy research organization KFF. If congressional Republicans hope to maintain their majority in the midterm elections this fall, then they need to address those concerns with credible, patient-centered reforms. They have already begun to do so, though those […]

item.title: [Texaspolicy] TrumpRx is a Game-Changer, Texas Can Go Even Farther
item.description:
President Trump’s TrumpRx initiative is a game-changer in the fight to lower prescription drug prices for everyday Americans. For far too long, prescription medication costs have been obscenely high, not because of the true cost of research and manufacturing, but because of a tangled web of insurance plans, middlemen, and opaque price-setting that enriches gatekeepers...

item.title: [Texaspolicy] Selective Enforcement Is Not Security, It’s Surrender
item.description:
Nations do not collapse overnight. They erode when leaders start deciding which laws are optional. It shows the American people that if immigration law only applies when it’s politically convenient, then it isn’t law—it’s theater. Maria Salazar, a Republican congresswoman from Texas recently said, “Don’t touch the nannies or the gardeners… Those people are helping...

item.title: [Pacificresearch] Cancer Breakthroughs Threatened by D.C.’s Price Controls
item.description:
Cancer survival rates are on the rise, according to the American Cancer Society’s latest annual report. Seven in 10 patients now live five years or more after a cancer diagnosis. Since 1991, reductions in smoking and improvements in disease management and earlier diagnosis have resulted in a 34% drop in the cancer death rate — […]

item.title: [Mountainstatespolicy] The soda tax is a sugar rush for bad policy
item.description: Now Washington state legislators want to take this experiment statewide, arguing that a new 3-cent sugar-sweetened beverage tax will improve health outcomes and fight hunger. It sounds noble. It sounds decisive. And it’s deeply disconnected from reality.

item.title: [Americanexperiment] Optum fraud report: big drop in Medicaid spending
item.description:
From KSTP-5 TV, Outside audit finds ‘recurring vulnerabilities’ with Minnesota Medicaid system. Details, The report estimates more than $1.7 billion in Medicaid payments that need a closer look to see if there were possible issues, including whether there were appropriate claims for service. That’s billion, with a “b”. So much euphemism. “Vulnerabilities,” “issues,” “appropriate,” “concerns,”...

item.title: [Idahofreedom] House Bill 570 — Reckless driving (0)
item.description: Bill Description: House Bill 570 would criminalize certain instances of speeding by deeming them reckless driving. This bill uses the phrase “in an active school zone or construction zone” where House Bill 490 says “in a school zone or construction zone.” The change […]
